text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

The case method is effective
because it's memorable.

Our brains are
wired for narrative.
And cases bring a story.

And that story
brings characters,

and the characters
are memorable.

Case method is gritty
because it's full of details.

And like real life, some of
those details are irrelevant.

And some of them are
the keys to the kingdom.

The students' ability and
then the class's ability

to sort through the signal
from the noise is, I think,
a critical skill.

Our job when we're doing it
well is to ask good questions.

That, of course, is what
managers, leaders everywhere
need to do.

They need to draw out the
intelligence of their employees

who after all are
the true experts,

whether because they're
in contact with customers

or because they bring
some special expertise
to the organization.

The "Children's Hospital
and Clinics" case

was the second
case study I wrote.

And it was the first
case for me where

I discovered the synergy
between case writing

research and journal-oriented
or academic scholarly research.

I had done work on psychological
safety, which is all about

whether people feel able to
speak up quickly and honestly
about the work at work.

The "Children's Hospital
and Clinics" case

tells the story of a general
manager named Julie Morath who

comes into this large
integrated health care delivery

system from the
outside to lead change.

Her aim is to dramatically
improve patient safety.

She leads a patient
safety initiative

where one of the cornerstones
of this initiative

is something called
blame-free reporting.

It's essentially a
change in policy.

It says no one will be
blamed for reporting
a problem that they see.

That policy of
blame-free reporting

was an earnest
attempt to increase

the psychological safety
of the organization

so that it could learn from its
own experiences and improve.

I learned so much more
about the phenomenon

of psychological safety--
how you create it,

why it matters, how it connects
to processes and structures

and team dynamics, and what
a leader can do to alter it.

And I really think
writing that case

played a large
role in my ability

to continue the research
on psychological safety,

put it in a broader context,
and make it far more impactful.

Teaching the "Children's
Hospital and Clinics" case

is a joy in part because
I know it so very well.

I'm attentive to
the details that

come out in the
conversation and the sense
that students make of them.

As time has gone
on, the case still

has deep relevance but in
new ways in a changing world.

Writing cases has made
my research better.

My research has made my cases
more interesting and impactful.

And the sum of the
parts is way greater.

It makes my work
more interesting.

It makes my teaching more
fun and more impactful.

And I can't imagine a
career without doing both.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
